docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court that opens its new term on Monday will be a court in transition, neither what it was when nine justices last sat together in June, nor what it will be when Justice Sandra Day O'Connor's successor arrives, freeing her to leave the bench some months later than she had planned. But it will be, indisputably, the Roberts Court.

headline.main: New Leader, Tough Issues for Court in Transition

docs.abstract: Supreme Court that opens its new term on October 3 will be court in transition, neither what it was when nine justices sat together in June, nor what it will be when Justice Sandra Day O'Connor's successor arrives, freeing her to leave bench some months later than she had planned; court will be, indisputably, the Roberts Court; court issued opinions in 123 cases 25 years ago, when Roberts was law clerk, but only 74 last term; shrinking docket has been source of frustration to lawyers who practice before court; Roberts suggested at his confirmation hearing, that he sees room for court to hear and decide more cases; if that comes to pass, it could be indication that Chief Justice Roberts is exerting influence on his colleagues just as Chief Justice Rehnquist, who thought court was taking on too many cases, managed to do in opposite direction; preview of some of cases court will hear; table shows Senate votes to confirm Supreme Court nominees, 1971-2005 (L)
docs.snippet: The Supreme Court that opens its new term on Monday will be a court in transition, but it will be, indisputably, the Roberts Court.

multimedia.credit: At the White House, the new chief justice thanked President Bush for selecting him.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: At the White House, the new chief justice thanked President Bush for selecting him.

docs.lead_paragraph: Generation RX How Prescription Drugs Are Altering American Lives, Minds and Bodies By Greg Critser 308 pages. Houghton Mifflin Company. $24.95. In his hilarious stand-up routine, Chris Rock talks about the ubiquitous television drug commercials that ''keep naming symptoms till they get one that'' the viewer's got. Sometimes, he says, the ads don't even tell you what the pill does: ''You see a lady on a horse or a man in a tub, and they just keep naming symptoms: 'Are you depressed?' 'Are you lonely?' 'Do your teeth hurt?''' He adds that one commercial he saw went, ''Do you go to bed at night and wake up in the morning?''

headline.main: Tense? Lonely? There's Promise in a Pill

docs.snippet: Greg Critser conveys the dramatic and disturbing ways in which the development and marketing of pharmaceuticals have changed over the last two decades.

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: GENERATION RX: HOW PRESCRIPTION DRUGS ARE ALTERING AMERICAN LIVES, MINDS AND BODIES (BOOK)
